speaker: RESIDENT
text: Hi, I’m one of the emergency room doctors. I understand you were getting an extra dialysis session today and started feeling very short of breath and light‑headed, and your blood pressure was low. Can you tell me in your own words what’s been going on over the last few days?

speaker: PATIENT
text: For a few days I’ve been getting more short of breath when I walk around. I thought it was fluid, so they brought me in for extra dialysis today. After they took fluid off I felt really weak, dizzy, like I was going to pass out. They told me my pressure was in the 80s. I never had chest pain, no cough or fevers.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Thank you. I see in your chart that you have HIV and are currently off your HIV medications, and you’re on hemodialysis for kidney failure. You also have a history of low blood pressure after dialysis in the past. Is that right?

speaker: PATIENT
text: Yes. I’ve had HIV for years. I haven’t been taking the HIV meds lately. I go to dialysis three times a week. Sometimes after dialysis my pressure drops and I feel like I might pass out. They stopped one of my blood pressure pills before because of that.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You also have a right groin dialysis catheter in place, and I see notes that you’ve had problems with clots in your central veins before, which made placing lines in your neck difficult. We may need to use that groin line for access today. We’re going to get blood tests, an EKG, and a chest X‑ray, and we’ll give you some fluids carefully. If your blood pressure stays low, we may need to use medications to support it for a short time.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’m scared about my blood pressure being so low, but do what you need to. Just be careful with the fluids because of my kidneys.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’ve checked your vital signs: your temperature is normal, your heart rate is in the 60s, your blood pressure is around 82 over 40, and your oxygen level is 100% on room air. Your lungs sound clear and your heart sounds regular. We’re going to start a small fluid bolus and a brief medication to support your blood pressure while we sort out the cause. We’ll also draw labs including kidney function, blood counts, and heart enzymes.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I don’t feel short of breath just lying here, just kind of wiped out and light‑headed.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your initial labs show your kidney numbers are high, as expected with your end‑stage renal disease: your creatinine is 8.6 and your BUN is 69. Your blood counts show a mild anemia and low platelets, and your white count is a bit low. Your troponin, a heart enzyme, is 0.42, which is higher than your usual baseline of around 0.15–0.25, but your CK and CK‑MB are not elevated. Your EKG doesn’t show any signs of a heart attack. We’ve asked cardiology to weigh in.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Does that mean I’m having a heart attack?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Right now, we don’t think so. The cardiology team feels that with no chest pain, a normal EKG, and flat CK and CK‑MB, the troponin bump is likely a mild leak from the low blood pressure and your kidney disease, not a classic heart attack. We’ll keep checking your heart enzymes, but they’re not recommending any invasive heart procedures at this time.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’ve done a chest X‑ray, which shows clear lungs and no signs of pneumonia or fluid overload. We’re also sending you for a CT angiogram of your chest to rule out a blood clot in your lungs, given your shortness of breath and low blood pressure.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’m not really short of breath now, but I was when I was walking earlier. I just want to make sure it’s not a clot.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Your CT angiogram is back. There’s no evidence of a pulmonary embolism. It does show narrowing of some of the large veins in your chest—the left subclavian and both brachiocephalic veins—with a lot of collateral veins, but the main vein to the heart, the SVC, is still open. That fits with your history of difficult central line placement. There’s no pneumonia or other lung problem on the scan.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So no clot in my lungs and no pneumonia. That’s good. Why did I get so short of breath then?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We think your shortness of breath was from being fluid overloaded before the extra dialysis, and then the low blood pressure happened after too much fluid was taken off. Your breathing improved after dialysis, but your pressure dropped. Right now your blood pressure is stabilizing with a small fluid bolus and brief support from medications, and your oxygen level has stayed normal.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: I’m the ICU attending. We’re going to admit you to the MICU for close monitoring of your blood pressure. You were briefly on a medication to support your pressure, but we’ve already been able to turn that off as your pressure improved with fluids. We’ll also start broad‑spectrum antibiotics tonight—vancomycin and piperacillin‑tazobactam—just in case there’s an infection causing low blood pressure, while we wait for cultures. If everything stays negative and you remain stable, we’ll stop them.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. I don’t feel sick like with an infection, but I understand you want to be safe.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’ve moved you up to the MICU. Your blood pressure is now in the low 100s systolic, which you say is close to your usual. You’re on the monitor, and your oxygen is still 100% on room air. If you feel dizzy or more short of breath, please call us right away.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel better than before, not really dizzy now. Just my usual headache.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: This morning your blood pressure has remained stable without any medications to support it. Your lactate, which was elevated when you were hypotensive, has come down. You’re not short of breath at rest, and your exam is unchanged. We’ll plan to transfer you out of the MICU to the regular medicine floor later today if things stay this way.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That sounds good. I’d rather be on a regular floor if I don’t need the ICU.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’ve repeated your labs. Your hemoglobin has dropped from 11.8 to 9.8, and your platelets are around 107. Your white count is still low at about 3.2. Your kidney numbers are a bit higher this morning—creatinine 9.9 and BUN 94—and your potassium is elevated at 7.1, with an anion gap of 25 and bicarbonate of 21. We’re arranging hemodialysis today to address the high potassium and volume status.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I know my blood counts are usually low, but the platelets being low is new? Is that from my HIV?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: You’re right—your anemia and low white count are chronic, but the thrombocytopenia is newer. We’re not sure of the exact cause yet. It could be related to bone marrow suppression from active HIV. We’re going to trend your platelets and also look for other causes, including checking for signs of lymphoma or other malignancy, since your LDH is elevated and you have some other lab abnormalities.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Lymphoma? That sounds scary. What are you going to do to check for that?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re starting with imaging. We’ve ordered an abdominal ultrasound to look at your spleen and lymph nodes in your abdomen, since lymphoma can cause an enlarged spleen or enlarged lymph nodes. We’re also doing more detailed blood tests, including protein electrophoresis and immunoglobulin levels, to see if there’s a pattern suggesting a blood cancer versus a more benign immune activation.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. I’d like to know what’s going on, but I’m nervous about more bad news.

speaker: NURSE
text: We’re getting you ready to go down for your abdominal ultrasound. After that, you’re scheduled for dialysis. Your blood pressure is stable and you’re on room air.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Alright. Will dialysis be the same as usual through my groin catheter?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, dialysis will be through your right groin catheter as usual. We’ll be careful about how much fluid we remove this time to avoid dropping your blood pressure again. Nephrology has ordered heparin, doxercalciferol, and your usual cinacalcet and sevelamer to continue your ESRD regimen.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Please tell them not to take too much fluid. I don’t want to feel like I did when I came in.

speaker: NURSE
text: You’re back from ultrasound. The radiologist’s preliminary read is that your spleen is borderline enlarged, but they don’t see any big lymph nodes in your abdomen. They also see a lot of cysts in your kidneys, which you’ve had before. We’ll let the team discuss the full report with you.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So they didn’t see any big tumors or anything?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: I’ve reviewed your abdominal ultrasound. Your spleen is borderline enlarged at 12.9 cm, slightly bigger than on a prior study, and there are a couple of small bright spots in the spleen that look like benign hemangiomas. There’s no sonographic evidence of enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes. Your kidneys have many cysts, which is unchanged. So, at this point, we don’t see imaging evidence of lymphoma in your abdomen.

speaker: PATIENT
text: That’s a relief. What about those blood tests you mentioned?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: The blood tests show your LDH is elevated, and your beta‑2 microglobulin, IgG, and IgM levels are all high. The protein electrophoresis pattern is consistent with polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia, which means your immune system is broadly activated rather than a single clone of cells overgrowing. That’s more consistent with chronic HIV‑related immune activation than with a classic lymphoma pattern, but we’ll need to follow these over time as an outpatient.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So it’s not definitely cancer, but you want my doctors to keep an eye on it later?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Exactly. Right now, we don’t have imaging or lab evidence that clearly points to lymphoma. We do see this polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia and elevated beta‑2 microglobulin, which we’ll flag for your outpatient team to monitor. If your platelets or other counts worsen, they may consider more invasive testing like a bone marrow biopsy, but that’s not planned during this short stay.

speaker: NURSE
text: Dialysis is starting now. The nephrology team has set a conservative fluid removal goal to avoid dropping your blood pressure. We’ll monitor your vitals closely during the session.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you. I’m feeling okay right now, just tired.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: You’ve done well overnight. Your blood pressure has stayed in your usual range without any support, and you haven’t had any more shortness of breath. Your oxygen levels have been normal, and your chest imaging and CT ruled out pneumonia and pulmonary embolism. Given your stability, we’re transferring you from the MICU to the medicine floor.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’m glad I’m breathing fine now. I don’t feel short of breath anymore, just my usual fatigue.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: On the floor, we’ll continue your regular Monday‑Wednesday‑Friday dialysis schedule. We’re also continuing your cinacalcet and sevelamer, and we’ve increased your sevelamer dose to better control your phosphorus. You’ll stay on Bactrim prophylaxis, and we’ve restarted azithromycin prophylaxis for MAC, since your CD4 count has been low. We’re not restarting full HAART during this admission because of prior non‑adherence; that will be coordinated with your outpatient HIV doctor.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I’ve been taking the Bactrim at home. I know I haven’t been good about the HIV meds. I’ll talk to my ID doctor about restarting them.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: This morning’s labs show your hemoglobin is 10.6, hematocrit 33.9, platelets 108, and white count 2.2. Your creatinine is 6.2 and BUN 51 after dialysis, potassium is 5.1, and your calcium is a bit low at 7.9. These are all acceptable for you, and there’s no sign of active bleeding. Your troponin has not risen further, and your EKG remains without ischemic changes.

speaker: PATIENT
text: So my blood counts are still low but stable, and my kidneys are about the same as usual after dialysis?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Yes, that’s right. Your anemia and leukopenia are chronic and stable, and the platelets are still low but not dropping further. Your kidney numbers are consistent with your ESRD and improve after dialysis. We’ll continue to monitor, but there’s no indication for transfusion.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: From a breathing and blood pressure standpoint, you’re doing well. Your shortness of breath has resolved, and your blood pressure has been stable on the floor. We think the hypotension was due to too much fluid being removed during that extra dialysis session. Your infectious workup, including blood cultures, has been negative, and you’ve been afebrile, so we’ve not continued broad‑spectrum antibiotics beyond the initial doses in the ED.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I feel back to my usual now. No shortness of breath, and I can walk to the bathroom with my cane.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: We also did an echocardiogram, which showed an atrial septal defect and mild mitral regurgitation, but your heart’s pumping function is normal and there’s no sign of significant pulmonary hypertension. These findings don’t change your management right now but will be important for your outpatient cardiology follow‑up.

speaker: PATIENT
text: I didn’t know I had a hole in my heart. As long as it’s not causing problems now, I’ll follow up as you say.

speaker: RESIDENT
text: We’re planning to discharge you home today. You’ll continue your regular dialysis schedule. We’re increasing your sevelamer dose to 4000 mg three times a day with meals to better control your phosphorus. Your discharge medications will include cinacalcet, sevelamer, Bactrim with each dialysis, weekly azithromycin, docusate, aspirin 81 mg, folic acid, hydroxyzine as needed for itching, and oxycodone‑acetaminophen as needed for pain.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Okay. Can you go over the changes again so I don’t miss anything when I get home?

speaker: RESIDENT
text: Of course. The main change is that your sevelamer dose is higher—4000 mg three times daily with meals. We’ve also formalized your prophylaxis: Bactrim with each hemodialysis session and azithromycin once weekly. Everything else is essentially a continuation of what you were already taking. We’ll send a detailed list with you, and your dialysis unit will also have the updated orders.

speaker: ATTENDING
text: Before you go, to summarize: you came in with shortness of breath and then low blood pressure after an extra dialysis session. We ruled out pulmonary embolism and heart attack, and your breathing and blood pressure normalized with a small fluid bolus and careful dialysis. We found some lab abnormalities—elevated LDH, beta‑2 microglobulin, and immunoglobulins, plus new thrombocytopenia—but imaging and blood studies suggest polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia rather than a clear lymphoma. These will need outpatient follow‑up. You’re stable, alert, and able to walk with assistance, so we’re comfortable sending you home today.

speaker: PATIENT
text: Thank you for explaining everything and for taking care of me. I’ll follow up with my kidney and HIV doctors like you said.
